perturbation.original_text:
Within 7 Business Days
after the end of each calendar quarter, the Billing Party shall provide the
other party with an itemized statement, subject to adjustment within 30 days of
receipt of such statement, setting forth the Net Revenue achieved over the
preceding calendar quarter, and shall include such other information as may be
mutually agreed upon by the parties (the "Revenue Report").
perturbation.changed_text:
Within 45 Business Days
after the end of each calendar quarter, the Billing Party shall provide the
other party with an itemized statement, subject to adjustment within 90 days of
receipt of such statement, setting forth the Net Revenue achieved over the
preceding calendar quarter, and shall include such other information as may be
mutually agreed upon by the parties (the "Revenue Report").
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates the Billing Party to furnish an itemized statement of Net Revenue within 7 business days after each calendar quarter's end, subject to adjustment within 30 days. Modifying this to 45 and 90 days respectively introduces a contradiction. Many jurisdictions have laws requiring timely and prompt financial reporting. Extending these periods significantly may not meet the standard of promptness required by law, which seeks to protect parties' rights to receive information and payments promptly.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law requiring good faith and fair dealing, which imply reasonable timeframes for financial reporting.

perturbation.original_text:
The Billing Party will bear the costs of such audit if a discrepancy
or error of computation in an amount greater than $10,000 in favor of the
Non-Billing Party is identified.
perturbation.changed_text: The Non-Billing Party will always bear the costs of such audit.
perturbation.explanation: The original agreement states the Billing Party bears the audit costs if a discrepancy exceeding $10,000 is found in favor of the Non-Billing Party. Changing this to always have the Non-Billing Party bear the costs could be seen as an unfair and unreasonable business practice. This is because it may deter the Non-Billing Party from exercising their audit rights, even if they suspect a substantial discrepancy. The change imposes an unreasonable financial burden, effectively nullifying the audit right.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law prohibiting unconscionable or oppressive terms.

perturbation.original_text:
Either party may terminate this Agreement at any
time in the event that the other party is in default or breach of any material
provision of this Agreement, and such default or breach continues unremedied for
a period of sixty days after written notice thereof.
perturbation.changed_text:
Either party may terminate this Agreement at any
time in the event that the other party is in default or breach of any material
provision of this Agreement, and such default or breach continues unremedied for
a period of ten days after written notice thereof.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that a party has 60 days to remedy a breach after written notice, before the other party can terminate. Reducing this period to 10 days introduces a potential conflict. Depending on the nature of the breach and the jurisdiction, 10 days may be considered an unreasonably short period to remedy a material breach. This is particularly true for complex issues or those requiring significant effort/investment to correct.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law requiring reasonable opportunity to cure a breach.
